title: Brief Resolved Unexplained Events (BRUE) Criteria for Infants
description: Classifies unexplained events in infants <1 year old and replaces the Apparent Life-Threatening Events (ALTE) classification. Determines risk stratification and management recommendations for infants who have experienced brief, resolved episodes of concerning symptoms.

parameters.name: age_under_1_year
parameters.description: Is the infant less than 1 year old?

parameters.name: asymptomatic_on_presentation
parameters.description: Is the infant asymptomatic on presentation (no URI symptoms, no fever)?

parameters.name: no_explanation_after_exam
parameters.description: No explanation for event after history and physical exam?

parameters.name: sudden_brief_resolved_episode
parameters.description: History of sudden, brief, and now resolved episode?

parameters.name: breathing_changes
parameters.description: Episode included absent, decreased, or irregular breathing?

parameters.name: tone_changes
parameters.description: Episode included marked change in tone (hyper or hypotonia)?

parameters.name: altered_responsiveness
parameters.description: Episode included altered level of responsiveness?

parameters.name: no_history_prematurity
parameters.description: No history of prematurity (≥32 weeks gestational age or ≥45 weeks postconceptional age if born <32 weeks)?

parameters.name: no_cpr_by_provider
parameters.description: No need for CPR by medical provider?

result.name: brue_classification
result.description: BRUE classification result and risk stratification

ranges.interpretation: The event does not meet the criteria for Brief Resolved Unexplained Event (BRUE). Consider alternative diagnoses and appropriate evaluation based on clinical presentation.

ranges.description: Meets BRUE criteria but classified as higher risk
ranges.interpretation: Meets BRUE criteria but does not meet all lower-risk criteria. Consider further evaluation, monitoring, and potential hospitalization based on clinical judgment and shared decision-making with family.

ranges.description: Meets BRUE criteria and classified as lower risk
ranges.interpretation: Meets criteria for lower-risk BRUE. May be managed with observation, parental education, CPR training resources, and shared decision-making. Routine diagnostic testing is not recommended.

references: Tieder JS, Bonkowsky JL, Etzel RA, et al. Brief resolved unexplained events (formerly apparent life-threatening events) and evaluation of lower-risk infants. Pediatrics. 2016;137(5):e20160590. doi: 10.1542/peds.2016-0590.

American Academy of Pediatrics Subcommittee on Apparent Life-Threatening Events. Apparent life-threatening events in infants: an evidence-based review. Pediatrics. 2003;111(2):361-7. doi: 10.1542/peds.111.2.361.

Mittal MK, Sun G, Baren JM. A clinical decision rule to identify infants with apparent life-threatening event who can be safely discharged from the emergency department. Pediatr Emerg Care. 2012;28(7):599-605. doi: 10.1097/PEC.0b013e31825cf576.
formula: BRUE classification is determined by meeting entry criteria (age <1yr, asymptomatic, no explanation, sudden brief episode) AND at least one qualifying event characteristic (color change, breathing change, tone change, or altered responsiveness). Lower risk requires ALL additional criteria to be met.
notes: BRUE replaced the term Apparent Life-Threatening Event (ALTE) in 2016
Lower-risk BRUE patients do not require routine diagnostic testing (chest x-rays, blood gas, sleep studies, ECG, etc.)
Emphasis on shared decision-making with families
Consider social risk factors for child abuse in all cases
Offer CPR training resources to families
Prematurity is defined as <32 weeks gestational age or <45 weeks postconceptional age for infants born <32 weeks
Higher-risk patients may require further evaluation and monitoring based on clinical judgment
